page.title: 07ARTIFICIAL RECLAMATION
page.content: China Clay extraction leaves the moorland scarred with pits and bespotted with tips, resulting in a lunar landscape loved by film-makers but hated by naturalists. The major producer, English China Clays, spent about 500,000 pounds in 1984 on landscaping and reclamation projects. These included in-filling pits, and grassing and levelling tips. It is argued that levelling improves the appearance and stability of the tips. Plants such as lupins and a mixture of grasses and clover have been planted and the hills stocked with Soay sheep, a hardy Scottish breed. In some places conifers from the company nursery at Carthew have also been planted. Many people think that the new, huge, featureless mounds are worse than the old conical "white pyramids".
